abstract.p: On-Line Entertainment Inc will present concert by Philadelphia Orchestra with violinist Itzhak Perlman in first pay-per-listen live Netcast under recent Classical Music Internet Agreement; photo; Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo begins two-week engagement at Joyce Theater; J Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles launches exhibition of illuminated manuscripts focused on Virgin Mary; photo; upcoming New York Fringe Festival will offer 175 theatrical and performance productions (Footlights column) (M)

block.p: A Musical First Taking advantage of the recent Classical Music Internet Agreement, which established compensation for musicians whose performances are made available on the World Wide Web, the Philadelphia Orchestra, with the violinist and conductor Itzhak Perlman, will be featured on Thursday in the first pay-per-listen live Netcast. The event, presented by On-Line Entertainment Network Inc., is to be broadcast from the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, with Beverly Sills moderating. For $2, listeners, who can log on a few minutes before the 8:15 p.m. curtain time at www.oen.com, will hear works by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms. The concert will be rebroadcast on the site after Sept. 1 for $1.

Dancing for Laughs Delicate and dainty they're not. Still, the members of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo are not without their charms. With stage names like Ida Nevasayneva, Mikolojus Vatissnyem and Igor Slowpokin, and decked out in oversize pointe shoes and tutus, the dancers in the all-male company are ''a cross between City Ballet and 'I Love Lucy,' '' said Tory Dobrin, the troupe's artistic director. Beginning tonight, the 24-year-old company will present its first New York performances of classics like ''Raymonda's Wedding'' and ''Russian Dance'' before leaping across centuries with Merce Cunningham's ''Cross Currents.'' The two-week engagement is at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea. Information: (212) 242-0800.

Exalted One Virgin mother, queen of heaven, intercessor: such were the roles assigned to the Virgin Mary throughout the Middle Ages and Renaissance, when her importance rivaled that of Jesus. Devotion to her took a variety of forms, but perhaps none were lovelier than illuminated manuscripts. Beginning tomorrow, ''The Queen of the Angels,'' an exhibition at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, will examine 400 years of these radiant works. A related exhibition, ''The Making of a Medieval Book,'' explains the labor-intensive process behind the images. Both run through Nov. 5. Information: (310) 440-7300.

Pushing Boundaries Fringe, fringe, everywhere. While the Festival Fringe opens across the Atlantic as part of the 2000 Edinburgh International Festival, those closer to home are honing their own envelope-pushing performances. Beginning on Wednesday, the New York International Fringe Festival will offer 175 productions by 2,000 artists, including Jimmy O'Neill's ''Life With Jeem,'' about the relationship between a gay man and the top half of a Macy's mannequin, and ''Five at the Fringe,'' a series of plays staged by members of the Drama League Directors Project. Information: (212) 420-8877.
